Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Enhancing robustness and generalizability in the social and behavioral sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most experimental studies in the behavioral sciences rely on college students as participants for reasons of convenience, and most take place in North America and Europe. As a result, studies are only sampling from a narrow range of human experiences. The results of these studies have limited generalizability, failing to reflect the full range of mental and behavioral phenomena across diverse cultures and backgrounds. However sampling from broader populations is challenging, due to limited opportunities and access, heightened cost, and the need for specific knowledge about how to adapt research protocols to different communities. The goal of this workshop is to develop some tools and guidelines to help researchers overcome barriers to broader sampling, and to incentivize doing so through better institutional support.

The goal of this workshop is to develop tools to support and encourage increased robustness and generalizability in the experimental behavioral sciences. The meeting is dedicated to identifying and developing potential solutions to the so-called "WEIRD people" problem: the fact that most experimental behavioral science research is conducted with members of WEIRD populations (Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich Democracies). The discovery that much of this research fails to generalize to broader populations and fails to capture the range of human patterned variation in thought and behavior creates a pressing need for research approaches to be more inclusive. Although there are researchers throughout the world who have developed effective models for overcoming these limitations, there are significant barriers to achieving robust and generalizable experimental behavioral research for most researchers. This workshop will bring together scholars from a range of disciplines whose research represents positive case studies of how to overcome these barriers. The participants aspire to accomplish three goals: 1) develop tools and training materials to help researchers enhance diversity in their research populations, 2) develop infrastructure solutions for connecting researchers across diverse contexts and populations, and 3) develop a set of recommendations for institutional changes to support enhancing diversity in experimental behavioral science through manuscript, grant, and tenure review.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

WORKSHOP: Enhancing robustness and generalizability in the social and behavioral sciences - BCS1647219

 

Robust and generalizable theories of human behavior are essential for improving policy in a range of areas, including education, savings, human capital investment, public health, workforce training, and decisions under uncertainty.  However, current findings in the social and behavioral sciences are based on an extremely narrow set of convenience samples, largely based in U.S. colleges.  Consequently, we know little about which results will generalize to other populations and which will not. This is a very serious limitation.

A workshop was held in Arlington, VA, March 13-14, 2017, with the aim of determining and implementing alternatives to the current extreme sampling bias favoring college students and other highly accessible study populations in the social and behavioral sciences.

The Workshop brought together a group of 27 key stakeholders (journal editors, granting agency program officers, university administrators) and researchers to identify what strategies would be most feasible and effective at improving the robustness and generalizability of findings and theories in the social and behavioral sciences. Scholars represented a range of disciplines and a mix of junior and senior scholars as well as scholars from under-represented groups.

In addition to the individually invited scholars, an invitation was extended to agency personnel and researchers. The approximately 20 attendees included representatives from NSF and the Association for Psychological Science, as well as other interested researchers. 

Specific goals of the workshop were:

1. Identifying and developing tools to enhance teaching and training for diversity

2. Identifying and developing infrastructure solutions for connecting researchers across diverse contexts and populations

3. Encouraging institutional changes in manuscript, grant, and tenure review that encourage greater diversity in social and behavioral sciences.  

Outcomes of the Workshop include:

1. Formation of a working group to to build training materials for for students and researchers interested in enhancing diversity in their own research

 

2. We proposed and received funding for a Sackler colloquium, held in September 2017, bringing together scholars whose work has addressed and illustrated the benefits of diversity and and addressing generalizability. This resulted in a special section of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, “Pressing Questions in the Study of Psychological and Behavioral Diversity” focused on the workshop themes of diversity and generalizability. In addition to calling attention to these issues the papers should constitute relevant readings for courses on diversity.  

3. Draft guidelines for behavioral and social science journals to increase sample diversity

In addition to the direct outcomes of this workshop, we hope our work will have two additional positive impacts.  One is to engage a broader range of communities in research in ways that will increase their appreciation of the benefits and relevance of empirical research. The other is that a broader range of participants will encourage scholars from those communities to themselves pursue careers in social and behavioral science research and increase the participation of under-represented groups in science. One encouraging sign is that the focus on study population diversity also was associated with diversity of research teams and PNAS authors.
